articles.title: Indonesia landslide kills 11 in Central Java, official says 12 missing
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: On Thursday, November 13, a landslide struck Cibeunying village in Cilacap, Central Java, burying around a dozen homes under mud and earth. Eleven people have been recovered so far, with three yesterday and eight today. 12 people remain missing.

articles.title: Devastation in Petit-Goâve: Hurricane Melissa's Aftermath
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: 43 people died as a result of Hurricane Melissa in Petit-Goâve in southern Haiti. The La Digue river overflowed, leading to the loss of 43 lives and leaving many missing. There was a significant outpouring of grief during a public ceremony for the deceased.

articles.title: Coastal voices call for urgent climate finance
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: A human chain and sit-in was held yesterday morning on the bank of the Pashur river at Kanainagar in Mongla to mark Climate Action Day. Speakers warned that urgent climate finance is essential to safeguard the lives and livelihoods of coastal communities and the Sundarbans.

articles.title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR: Please dive deeper into the science
articles.summary: Guest viewpoint blames climate change on human population increases. In the last 10,000 years, 1/3 of the forests have been cleared, according to the guest viewpoint.    .   in the editor's opinion, climate change is caused by human population increase.

articles.title: Outdoors: Quail future in Texas will require massive efforts and dollars
articles.author: The Panola Watchman
articles.summary: Quail numbers in the U.S. have dipped 75% since the 1980s. The High Plains had good conditions throughout the nesting season. There was an increase in the average number of bobwhites seen per route compared to last year.

articles.title: At least four dead as two migrant boats capsize off Libyas coast, Red Crescent says
articles.author: Live Mint
articles.summary: Two migrant boats have capsized off Libya's coast, Red Crescent reports. At least four people are dead as a result of the capsizing, the Red Crescent says. The cause of the incident remains unknown.       in Libya's Mediterranean Sea.

articles.title: The rural mum helping flip the school postcode lottery
articles.author: Stephanie Gardiner
articles.summary: Ms Ferrari was born and raised in Sydney. She left the city as a young woman and moved to the southern highlands. She used to say that she had taken a wrong turn when she left Sydney and now she feels like she belongs in the south-west.

articles.title: First Freeze Dates Have Trended Nearly Two Weeks Later In Some SD Cities Since 1970, Report Says
articles.author: Makenzie Huber © 2025
articles.summary: First freeze dates in South Dakota are trending later in the year. The trend is 1.4 days later per decade, according to a Midwestern Regional Climate Center freeze date tool. The longer growing season has lengthened the growing season and increased risks from weeds, pests and wildfires.

articles.title: 4 irregular migrants die as 2 boats carrying dozens capsize off Libya's coast
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Two boats carrying nearly 100 people capsized off the coast of Al-Khums in northwestern Libya, the Libyan Red Crescent reports. Four migrants died in one of the boats. The Red Crescent received a report late Thursday about two boats capsizing off the Al Khums coast.

articles.title: The Coalition is spinning a lie that climate action is economically bad. How are they getting away with it?
articles.author: Zoe Daniel
articles.summary: During the last parliament I negotiated an amendment to the Climate Change Act to lock in Australia's carbon emissions target as a floor, not a ceiling. I did it to promote government ambition to exceed the target and to provide a legislative buffer against backsliding by a future Australian government. We live in times where populist policy trumps people. Fossil fuel interests are winning the hearts and minds of voters. The rest of us who care about effective climate policy are being drowned out.

articles.title: UN climate summit sends a message of global ‘mutirao'
articles.author: Yossi Mekelberg
articles.summary: 50,000 delegates from 190 countries are in Belem for COP30, the annual UN climate change conference. The Global North has lost its enthusiasm for tackling the climate crisis, while the Global South shows resilience and is moving toward sustainability. Many countries are still neglecting their responsibilities. Brazil suggests adopting a different approach based on the concept of mutirao.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: LNG expansion could bring 200 more tankers a year to B.C.'s West Coast, report says
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: LNG expansion in B.C. could bring 200 more tankers a year to West Coast. Lack of Metro Vancouver charging stations hampers electric vehicle uptake. Oil and gas lobbyists outnumber delegates at COP30 in Brazil. Human activities like burning fossil fuels and farming livestock are the main drivers of climate change.

articles.title: Stunning images of Baracoa after the river Miel's rise
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The intense rains that have been pounding the city of Baracoa since early Saturday morning have caused a rise of the Miel River. The most affected neighborhoods are Bohórquez, Cabacú, Reparto Dap, Dos Caminos, the Combinado Cárnico (Slaughterhouse) area, and Vega Larga. Some residents report that the flooding caught them off guard without an evacuation plan and without immediate support from the authorities. Local authorities insist that there is no imminent danger.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu Braces for Torrential Downpour: Government Urges Precaution
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: There is a heavy rainfall alert from the India Meteorological Department (IMD). The weather system influenced by an upper air circulation has resulted in low pressure over southeast Sri Lanka coasts. The IMD report forecasts heavy to very heavy rainfall across northeast, delta, and coastal districts of Tamil Nadu over the next four days.

articles.title: Amazon River Hits 41°C: Record Heat Triggers Ecological Crisis
articles.summary: The Amazon region is experiencing unprecedented heat, with river temperatures soaring to 41°C. This extreme event poses a severe threat to the local ecosystem, raising concerns among environmentalists and scientists about potential widespread ecological damage in the region. The extreme event is raising urgent concerns among scientists and environmentalists.

articles.title: Nature Claims Their Circulation Is Decreasing
articles.author: Willis Eschenbach
articles.summary: A new study claims that the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) has been slowing since the 1990s. Willis Eschenbach is skeptical of the study's conclusions. He points out that pre-1980 data in the equatorial Atlantic is sparse, riddled with gaps, and heavily interpolated.

articles.title: CARICOM And IDB Partner On Framework To Measure Poverty And Vulnerability
articles.author: CARICOM
articles.summary: Caricom and Inter-American Development Bank partner on a statistical framework to measure poverty and vulnerability in the Region. The initiative will be piloted in The Bahamas, Belize, Guyana, and Trinidad and Tobago. It will produce regional knowledge products, methodological guidelines and training modules for administering multipurpose surveys to assess economic, social, and environmental vulnerabilities in participating countries.

articles.title: Mapped: Countries That Eat the Most Meat Per Capita
articles.author: Marcus Lu
articles.summary: The Kingdom of Tonga is the world's leading meat eater, followed by Mongolia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Hong Kong SAR, United States, Marshall Islands, Argentina, Argentina 113, Israel 113, Macau 113, Australia 112, Bahamas 108, Nauru 108, Samoa 105, Spain 105, Brazil 98, Portugal 98.8, French Polynesia 96, Belarus 94.5, Croatia 94.2, Iceland 93.4, Antigua and Barbuda 92.9, Chile 92.1, Saint Lucia 91,8, Canada 91.0, Ireland 90.7, Saint Kitts and Nevis 89,7, Barbados 88

articles.title: Thousands march outside COP30 summit in call for action
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Thousands march outside COP30 summit in call for action. First week of COP30 marked by frustration with slow progress and lack of progress on climate change issues.   http://www.cop30.org/news/press-releases/copen30-summit-first-week-marked-by-frustration-with-slow progress.

articles.title: Protesters demand N.L. premier take climate change seriously in wake of wildfires
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Richest 1% used 2025 carbon budget in 10 days
articles.summary: The richest 1% exhaust their fair share of the 2025 global carbon budget within the first 10 days of the year. Fifty of the world's wealthiest individuals emit more carbon in 90 minutes than the average person does in their entire lifetime. The disparity in carbon emissions between the wealthiest and the poorest has never been more glaring.

articles.title: Massive march in Brazil marks first big UN climate protest in years
articles.author: Facundo Fernández Barrio
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of the city hosting COP30 talks on Saturday. Indigenous people and activists sang, chanted and whirled to blasting music. They pushed along a giant beach ball of Earth and held a flag of Brazil with the words "Protected Amazon."

articles.title: Heavy Rain & Instability: Weekend Weather Alert ⚠️
articles.summary: Storm Claudia is bringing heavy rain, fierce winds, and snowfall to the Iberian Peninsula. The Mediterranean Sea is warming at a rate 20% faster than the global average. Rising temperatures are exacerbating droughts, increasing the risk of wildfires, and fueling more intense storms in the Mediterranean region.

articles.title: Thousands take to streets of Glasgow to highlight ‘climate emergency'
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Thousands march for climate action outside COP30 summit in Brazil
articles.summary: Thousands march for climate action outside COP30 summit in Brazil. UN conference hits halfway mark. Indigenous and other climate activists say they need to make their voices heard as UN conference is about to reach halfway mark and they want to have their voice heard as well.

articles.title: Creation needs protection, love, justice and peace
articles.author: Fr. Shay Cullen
articles.summary: Philippines has been battered by devastating storms in recent weeks. World leaders gathered at the UN Climate Change Conference in Brazil have to continue serious efforts in bringing global warming under control. The efforts to mitigate the negative effects of climate change are being thwarted by the fossil fuel industry. Renewable energy has just overtaken fossil fuel as the main source of electricity in the EU.

articles.title: Maine Announces $550K in Grants to Boost Coastal Resilience
articles.summary: Maine Office of Community Affairs announced $550,000 in grant funding to help coastal communities prepare for storms, flooding and other climate-related risks. The state expects to award grants in early 2026 and the projects must be completed by March 31, 2027.

articles.title: How insufficient climate funding is exposing Africa to billions in avoidable losses
articles.author: Data Analyst
articles.summary: Africa needs $51 billion a year to adapt to worsening droughts, floods and wildfires, but receives only a quarter of that amount. According to the report, Africa risks forfeiting $6 trillion in potential economic benefits by 2035 if climate-proofing investments continue to lag. 95 percent of Africa's adaptation finance in 2023 came from public sources.

articles.title: COP30: Crowds march on doorstep of UN climate talks in Brazil
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Crowds march on the doorstep of UN climate talks in Brazil to protest against the UN's climate change agenda.    .   i   Read More at Article Source.  Read more at article source. Read more on BBC's website.

articles.title: Nagapattinam fishermen advised not to venture into sea till November 17
articles.author: Dtnext Bureau
articles.summary: Nagapattinam fishermen advised not to venture into the sea till November 17 due to inclement weather. Low-pressure system has formed over the Southwest Bay of Bengal off the Sri Lanka coast. Wind speed would prevail between 45 kmph and 55 kmph off the Tamil Nadu coast.

articles.title: Survey Reveals Kiwis Concerned About Natural Hazards Driving Up Insurance Costs
articles.author: Lotto New Zealand
articles.summary: New Zealanders are concerned about the impact of natural hazards on property insurance premiums. The most popular actions New Zealanders want to see to reduce the risk of insurance becoming unavailable are restricting building in high-risk areas and investing in stronger flood defences and infrastructure.

articles.title: Blane Klemek Outdoors: Enjoying the company of year-round birds
articles.summary: There are many birds that live in Minnesota all year round. They include blue jays, black-capped chickadee, white-breasted nuthatches, downy and hairy woodpeckers, American crow, common raven, ruffed grouse, great horned owl and barred owl are permanent year-round residents.

articles.title: Floods in Muwasi: Gaza's Struggle Against Nature and Conflict
articles.author: Deiral-Balah
articles.summary: Heavy rains have caused flooding in the Muwasi tent camp in the Gaza Strip. 80% of Gaza's population has been displaced due to ongoing war. The situation is exacerbated by an uncertain ceasefire agreement following a Hamas-led attack on October 7, 2023.

articles.title: COP30 makes individual climate actions seem small. That's why experts say to work in groups
articles.author: Ellen Schmidt
articles.summary: Activists participate in a demonstration for climate finance outside the COP30 U.N. Climate Summit venue in Belem, Brazil, on Thursday, Nov. 13, 2025. The article has been given to subscribers for free. To give it to friends and family for free, click here.

articles.title: Tom Selleck Addresses Possibility of ‘Boston Blue' Appearance After ‘Blue Bloods' Cancellation
articles.author: Michelle Stein
articles.summary: Griffin, GA (30223) is mostly sunny today. High 76F. Winds WSW at 5 to 10 mph. Tomorrow will be partly cloudy, with a high of 76F and low of 55F. It will be windy, with high winds of 10 to 15 mph.

articles.title: Displaced Gazans Face More Misery as Torrential Rain Lashes Enclave
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Heavy rainfall and chilling winds have added to the challenges facing people still forced to live in tents in the devastated territory. It is raining heavily and windy in the affected area. It's cold and wet in the rest of the territory.

articles.title: Northern Vietnam braces for deep freeze
articles.summary: On land, northeast winds will reach levels 3-4 (12-28 km/h), with coastal winds at levels 4-5 (about 29-38 km/hr). On land, on land, the northeast wind will reach level 3.4, with coastal areas at level 4.5. On November 17-18, northern Vietnam will see rain and showers, with thunderstorms in some areas. From the night of November 17, northern and north central Vietnam will experience cold weather, with some highland areas experiencing severe cold. In Hanoi, minimum temperatures are forecast at 12-15°C. The cold air, combined with upper-level easterly disturbances

articles.title: Wildlife dept tackles climate change impact on rare species in Punjab
articles.summary: The Wildlife Department of the Punjab government is working to protect rare birds and animals in Sargodha division with full support from the Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz Sharif. Arooj Zaheer, the Wildlife Assistant Chief for the region, highlighted climate change as one of the most pressing challenges Pakistan faces today. She called for nature-based solutions to tackle climate challenges.

articles.title: Commentary: The Island Nation of Jamaica's Recovery and Future Risks
articles.author: Winston Barnes
articles.summary: Jamaica and the rest of the English-speaking Caribbean are at a crucial point in their history. The goodwill being expended in Jamaica following the devastation of Hurricane Melissa is a chance for a new start, but it might be risky. Some of the assistance coming to the island nation might just come with additional benefits. The U.S. appears to be stepping up its pressure on Venezuela, which suggests an attack could come at any time.

articles.title: Climate limit set to be surpassed
articles.summary: Scientists say the planet will enter the danger zone before any long-term cooling begins. UN officials and scientists are pinning their hopes on forcing global temperatures back below the red line they set in the 2015 Paris Agreement, which sought to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius since preindustrial times. The idea behind overshoot is that once the world's emissions of CO2 are reduced over time, the temperature will drop.

articles.title: Baracoa floods again: Rising river Miel leaves areas underwater and residents in despair
articles.author: Cibercuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The intense rains that have been affecting the city of Baracoa, in Guantánamo, since early Saturday morning caused a new rise in the Miel River. The neighborhoods most affected are Bohorque, Cabacú, Reparto Dap, Dos Caminos, the Combinado Cárnico (Slaughterhouse) area, and Vega Larga. Residents report that they have not received immediate support from the authorities.

articles.title: After half-a-century in nature, a veteran birder says Manitoba's species are changing ‘tremendously'
articles.author: Danton Unger
articles.summary: Rudolf Koes has been a birder in Winnipeg for nearly six decades. Last year, 46 species of birds were observed during the Christmas Bird Count, including a swamp sparrow, a herring gull and a house finch. A changing climate has had a national impact on the number of species sticking around.

articles.title: On Nature column: How insects survive the winter freeze
articles.author: Sheryl Myers
articles.summary: The sub-freezing temperatures of winter can cause serious stress in living things. Hypothermia sets in when the body's core temperature drops below 95 degrees. If ice crystals form inside living cells, their jagged points rupture the cell membrane and cause cell death (frostbite).

articles.title: Shouting the best way to deter chip-stealing gulls
articles.summary: University of Exeter researchers studied how to deter seagulls from stealing human food without resorting to violence or flapping your arms. They recorded five male volunteers speaking and shouting the words 'No! Stay away! That's my food, that's my pasty!' at locations across nine towns in Cornwall, south-western England. The results showed that the gulls were more likely to walk away from the men speaking, but flew away when the same words were shouted.

articles.title: The Philippines estimates US$63mil damage to crops after typhoons
articles.author: Ditas Lopez
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi and Fung-Wong damaged rice and other harvests in the Philippines earlier this month. Total agricultural damage estimated at 3.7 billion pesos ($62.6 million). More than 19 million tons of rice, corn, and other crops were lost. About 36,630 hectares of farmland and nearly 55,000 farmers were affected.

articles.title: Delhi's pollution driven largely by PM10, 62 hotspots identified: Minister
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The onset of winter is worsening the smog situation, he said. The accumulated dust is gradually turning into smog, he added. The smog is caused by the snowfall and the cold weather. The situation is getting worse with each passing day.

articles.title: City of Cape Town appoints South Africa's first Chief HEAT Officer
articles.author: Garrin Lambley
articles.summary: Albert Ferreira has been appointed as South Africa's first Chief Heat Officer. He will lead efforts to improve heat awareness and coordinate interventions aimed at protecting residents. Cape Town is experiencing more frequent and severe heat events due to climate change. The city recorded its highest temperature ever: 44.6 degrees Celsius at the Royal Yacht Club on the Foreshore in 2024.

articles.title: Kalaburgi Children Warm by Fires as Winter Temperatures Plunge
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: Kalaburgi faces harsh winter with temperatures dropping to 1.2°C. Children gather around small fires to keep warm. Tamil Nadu issues a weather warning for the coastal district of Thoothukutti, advising fishermen to avoid venturing into the sea until further notice.

articles.title: Rapid melt from Antarctica could help preserve crucial ocean current
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Greenland's melt is expected to slow the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation. A collapse of the West Antarctic ice sheet could prevent it from shutting down, according to some research.    -      in some cases the ice sheet collapse could prevent the Circulation shutting down.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa a ‘real-time case study' of colonialism's legacies
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Destruction in Jamaica shows why climate justice cannot be separated from reparatory justice, campaigners say.    "It's not about politics, it's about justice" says one of the campaigners. "There's no difference between politics and justice. It's both.

articles.title: Climate activists demand compensation, protection of Sundarbans
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: A human chain and sit-in were held this morning on the bank of Pashur river at Kanainagar in Mongla to mark Climate Action Day. Speakers warned that urgent climate finance is essential to safeguard the lives and livelihoods of coastal communities and the Sundarbans.

articles.title: Fighting climate change with imaginative methods in East-Timor
articles.author: Juliette Chaignon
articles.summary: Global warming is wreaking havoc on the fishing industry in East Timor. The isolated island nation and its 1.4 million people face coastal erosion, rising sea levels and dwindling marine resources. Local people are using imaginative methods to tackle overfishing. France 24 travels to Brazil for the COP 30 climate change conference.

articles.title: As Glaciers Melt, the Earth's Cryosphere Is on Thin Ice
articles.author: Paloma Beltran
articles.summary: Miriam Jackson is a glaciologist, climate scientist and the Eurasia and Nordic director of the International Cryosphere Climate Initiative. She has just given a presentation at COP30 on the current state of the cryosphere. Since 2000, many glaciers have lost 20 percent of their mass. People in high mountain areas use the water for melting glaciers for water supply and for tourism. Glaciers will affect the sea level.

articles.title: Plan for sea-level rise in community workshops this December
articles.summary: The second round of community workshops dedicated to sea-level rise will focus on island roads and infrastructure that are at risk due to rising tides and eroding banks. The workshop schedule includes: False Bay Road at False Bay (San Juan Island), Deer Harbor Road at West Sound (Orcas Island), Port Stanley Road at Swifts Bay (Lopez Island), and Blind Bay road at Blind Bay (Shaw Island). Each site was chosen for its representation of different scenarios.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa a ‘real-time case study' of colonialism's legacies
articles.author: Natricia Duncan
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed a church in the village of Cold Spring in Hanover, Jamaica. 45 people died and 360,000 people were affected by the storm. The World Bank announced last week that the government of Jamaica would receive a full payout of $150m under its catastrophe insurance coverage. Activists argue that African descendants are disproportionately affected by centuries of environmental degradation.

articles.title: Kilwa Kisiwani: World Heritage Site with good, abundant marine resources
articles.author: Daily News Reporter
articles.summary: Kilwa Kisiwani is an island, national historic site and hamlet community located in the township of Kilwa Masoko in the Tanzanian region of Lindi in southern Tanzania. The island is 23 km (14 mi) in circumference and the total land area is 12 km2 (4.6 sq mi). The main economic activities on the island are cultural tourism, fishing and subsistence agriculture. Kilwa is one of the seven World Heritage Sites in Tanzania and a registered National Historic Site.

articles.title: Free NCTC lecture with Dean Allen on rewilding and wildlife tourism
articles.author: Janis Reeser
articles.summary: Dean Allen will present a lecture on his book "The Man Who Changed a Landscape: The Adrian Gardiner Story Rewilding and Wildlife Tourism in South Africa" at 7 p.m. Nov. 18 at the Byrd Auditorium at the National Conservation Training Center, 698 Conservation Way, Shepherdstown. The program is free and open to the public.

articles.title: Keep Maine's climate and environmental issues in the news
articles.author: Deb Sayer
articles.summary: Rebecca Fox appreciates the Press Herald's focus on environmental issues. She is concerned about the recent announcement by President Trump to restart nuclear testing and the need for independent news to promote facts, research and ideas surrounding our health and the health of the planet.

articles.title: Look to the skies and see migration in full action this autumn
articles.author: Callum Maggs
articles.summary: Autumn is a great time to look for birds on the move. Berks, Bucks & Oxon Wildlife Trust run events focused on birds at the Nature Discovery Centre. The event includes a talk about birds and nature, and a walk around the site to see what is about.

articles.title: Significant Damage Diagnosed to Coffee Plantations in the Municipality of Manuel Tames
articles.author: Radio Guantanamo
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa devastated the coffee plantations in Manuel Tames. The current harvest was expected to yield 8,000 cans of Arabica coffee and 25,000 can of Robusta coffee. Work is underway to harvest an additional 5,000 Arabica cans of coffee and 15,000 Robusto cans.

articles.title: How to help farmers adapt to climate smart agriculture
articles.summary: Africa accounts for 3.8 percent of the greenhouse gas emissions globally. Africa is most exposed to the impacts of climate change. If the continent warms by 2 degrees Celsius by 2050, crop yields across sub-Saharan Africa will reduce by 10 percent. About 70 percent of households in Uganda depend on small-scale farming for food and income. Peter Bamwesigye patrols the district helping farmers to increase their resilience to short-term climate shocks.

articles.title: IEA report admits commitment to climate change is melting away
articles.author: The Exposé
articles.summary: In a new report, the IEA admits that countries' commitment to climate change action is declining rapidly. The IEA had been predicting that 'fossil' fuel will be replaced by renewable energy sources in the future. Please share your story with iReport.

articles.title: (S+) World Climate Summit in Brazil: Glory and Misery of Belém – a City at the Limit
articles.summary: The rainforest metropolis is hosting the World Climate Conference. It is the scene of dramatic consequences of climate change. The poor inhabitants meet the tragedy of earth heating. The conference is taking place in a rainforest city.      Â

articles.title: Kerry needs to unite to protect UNESCO site amid climate change fears
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: There are fears that climate change could have serious consequences. There are also fears that it could have a negative impact on people's lives and livelihoods. There is also concern about the impact of climate change on humans and the environment. It is estimated to be worse than previously thought.

articles.title: What would an 'overshoot' of 1.5°C mean for the planet?
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement sought to limit global warming to 1.5°C since preindustrial times. Last year, Earth warmed by 1.3°C. The limit is based on temperatures averaged over a decade. It will be breached in the coming years or decades. There is a risk of irreversible changes in Earth systems when the limit is breached.

articles.title: Kerry needs to unite to protect UNESCO site amid climate change fears
articles.author: Sinead Kelleher
articles.summary: New report launched which identifies further steps to protect Skellig Michael off the Kerry coast. Climate change is the fastest growing global threat to heritage sites, including UNESCO World Heritage Properties. Measures outlined include increased local involvement to maintain and bolster economic, social and cultural values related to the site.

articles.title: Can we climate-proof our coastal towns?
articles.summary: Buet-led research team says 22 urban centres across 10 coastal districts now face heightened threats from river erosion, salinity, cyclones, and acute water scarcity. Coastal upazila towns have become the first destination for climate-displaced families from more vulnerable areas, resulting in heavy population pressure and deteriorating living conditions. In Satkhira city alone, the population has surged from 1.13 lakh in 2011 to over 2 lakh.

articles.title: Global Agricultural Losses Hit $3.26 Trillion, Says FAO
articles.author: Attia Naveed
articles.summary: Global agricultural losses reached $3.26 trillion over 33 years. Asia suffered the highest share of losses with 47 percent of the global total. Pakistan faced severe damage as monsoon floods destroyed 849,000 hectares of crops and impacted more than nine million people. FAO urged countries to expand disaster assessments and protect food systems.

articles.title: List of top 7 lakes that change colour with seasons
articles.author: Smarica Pant
articles.summary: There are seven colour-changing lakes around the world that are famous for their dramatic seasonal colour changes. Some of them shift shades throughout the year, while others change colour within weeks or even days. The colour changes depend on the intensity of sunlight and water temperature, and the presence of algae.

articles.title: Melissa devastation renews calls to strengthen Jamaica's food security
articles.author: Olivia Brown Gleaner Writer
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed 41,390 hectares of farmland and affected 7,000 farmers. The livestock sector suffered heavily, with about 1.2 million animals lost. The government is rolling out a $3 billion recovery programme to rehabilitate the sector and help farmers rebuild. 55.1% of Jamaica's population experienced moderate or severe food insecurity in the period 2021 to 2023. John-Paul Bramwell, lecturer at the Caribbean Maritime University, said food security is tied to national stability.

articles.title: Weekend Island Weather - Moderate trades and drier weather for the weekend
articles.author: Pete Caggiano
articles.summary: Tonight, there will be partly cloudy skies with lows in the middle 70s. There will be moderate trade winds and partly-mostly sunny skies on Saturday. East-northeast winds will be at 15 to 20 mph with higher gusts on Sunday and Monday. Rain chances go up Tuesday and Wednesday with a new disturbance developing near the islands. Small Craft Advisory is in effect for offshore waters around Maui County and the Big Island until 6 a.m. Saturday.

articles.title: Dublin, Wicklow & Wexford Flooding: Rain Alert Impact ☔️
articles.summary: There is an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme rainfall events in Ireland due to climate change. The recent flooding across Dublin, Wicklow and Wexford was directly linked to Storm Claudia. Ireland's geographical location and changes in the jet stream make it vulnerable to Atlantic storms and heavy rainfall. The agricultural sector is particularly vulnerable to increased flooding.

articles.title: Warmer, Wetter and Windier
articles.summary: Bill Gates is pessimistic about climate change. State Farm insurance will no longer write homeowner insurance policies in California. Insurers in Texas, Florida, and Louisiana are also pulling back due to increasing natural disasters including flooding. The world is getting warmer, wetter, and windier, and the air is getting dirtier.

articles.title: Maine announces $550K in grants to help coastal communities prepare for future storms
articles.author: NEWS CENTER Maine Staff
articles.summary: $550,000 in grants will help coastal communities prepare for storms, flooding and other climate-related risks. Individual applicants can apply for up to $50,000, while group applicants can seek $75,000. The grants can help towns study long-term coastal risks, plan or design stronger infrastructure, improve access to the coast and update local planning rules.

articles.title: IGAD weather centre predicts intensified drought in Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia
articles.author: Bruhan Makong
articles.summary: The Horn of Africa is facing an intensifying drought crisis. New climate forecasts indicate a high probability of continued below-normal rainfall through January 2026. The current sea surface temperature anomalies mirror patterns observed during the severe droughts of 2010 and 2022. The negative Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is expected to persist through December 2025, while La Niña conditions could last until February 2026, worsening the situation.

articles.title: The inevitability of Fortress Aotearoa and the need for Drones
articles.author: Martyn Bradbury
articles.summary: The climate crisis is getting worse and faster than expected. Global warming is destroying the planet and damaging the ability for the economy to function. China's heatwave is the most extreme heat event ever recorded in world history. Societies around the world are at risk of 'extreme political destabilisation', with declines in public trust, while the climate crisis intensifies. The radical adaptation required to get us ready for what's coming will splinter the political spectrum whether we like it.

articles.title: Bad weather alert: Thoothukudi fishers warned not to venture into sea
articles.author: Dtnext Bureau
articles.summary: Authorities have issued a weather warning for the coastal district of Thoothukudi, advising fishermen to avoid venturing into the sea until further notice due to the likelihood of strong winds and rough sea conditions. Fishermen who have already set out to sea have been urged to return to the shore immediately. Rescue teams and disaster response units have been instructed to remain on standby in case the weather situation worsens.

articles.title: Bangladesh may be among worst sufferers of heat stress
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Bangladesh's temperature has risen by nearly 6°C over the last decade. Economic losses due to heat is projected to increase to US$2,400 billion in 2030. Urban expansion, deforestation, and shrinking green spaces exacerbate temperature rise. Green infrastructure can reduce surface temperatures by up to 3°C, flexible work hours, and hydration access for informal workers can be effective.

articles.title: Gates' 2.9°C claim
articles.author: Peter Singer
articles.summary: Bill Gates believes that climate change is a serious problem, but it will not be the end of civilization. Peter Singer questions the UNFCCC's 2°C limit on global warming. He argues that it is not possible to keep warming below 2 °C and it will be far worse for human welfare than doing everything to keep it below 2%.

articles.title: JACKSONVILLE STATE 74, COASTAL CAROLINA 67
articles.author: Sportradar
articles.summary: R.Hill, Peat, Beadle, Dancler, Jones, Thompson, Ngopot, Craig, MacVicar, and C.C.H. scored 67 points for the game. C.Carolina is now 2-2 in the league.

articles.title: Australia to Make Eleventh-Hour Bid to Seal COP31 Deal
articles.author: The Canberra Times
articles.summary: The next host of the world's biggest climate conference must be decided within days. Australia is doing all it can to secure its bid to be the next host, and is working hard to secure the position.       i.e. to host the event.

articles.title: Heat deaths rise as world emissions hit record high
articles.author: 于小明
articles.summary: Global carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels are set to hit a record high in 2025, increasing 1.1 percent over 2024. The goal of slowing global warming to 1.5 C is out of reach. Brazil presented its first global climate adaptation plan centered on health at the COP30 on Thursday.

articles.title: Officials issue warning as bustling US neighborhood faces looming threat: 'Everyone knew that there was a risk'
articles.author: Mandy Carr
articles.summary: The Boston Seaport brings in 10% of the property tax revenue for the city. Rising sea levels are threatening to flood the area, which is home to restaurants, beer gardens, swanky condos, and law firms. The area was almost bankrupt in the 1980s, when developers wanted to build on the land.

articles.title: Climate Change and You: Will COP30 offer a breakthrough in fighting the climate crisis
articles.author: Bibek Bhattacharya
articles.summary: Bibek Bhattacharya and Sayantan Bera started the Climate Change and You newsletter a year ago. The first edition was published on the eve of the COP29 climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan. This year's COP30 is taking place in Belem, a city on the outskirts of Brazil's Amazon rainforest. Bill Gates created controversy by claiming a false dichotomy between urgent climate finance and global poverty alleviation.

articles.title: Devastating storm may open a new door
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Kalmaegi hit the coastal provinces from Gia Lai to Đắk Lộc on November 6. Hundreds of fishing boats were destroyed, sunk or tossed onto the shore. More than 1,000 houses were destroyed or had their roofs blown off, and 54,000 cages of aquaculture products were lost. The government has allocated VNĐ80 billion (US$3 million) to help the people of Quễn Mỹ Hà recover, but it will take time to repair the boats before fishermen can set sail again. The Department of Fisheries proposed cutting 6,000 fishing boats by

articles.title: Australia to make eleventh-hour bid to seal COP31 deal
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: Australia will make a last-ditch attempt to host the world's biggest climate conference in a bid to end a years-long deadlock and bring a long-term political impasse to an end. The conference will take place in Melbourne.

articles.title: Red flag warning
articles.author: Robert Hunziker
articles.summary: Antarctica has moved to the front of the line as a global warming threat that's already well beyond expectations and happening fast. 450 polar scientists held an emergency meeting in Australia d/d November 2024 issuing a press release to the public: 'If we don't act, the melting of Antarctica ice could cause catastrophic sea level rise around the globe within our lifetimes'

articles.title: When The Warm Train Exits
articles.author: Jim Kosek
articles.summary: The current source of air from the west-southwest will continue to pile in to start off the weekend. High pressure forming over warm water over the Gulf of Alaska and off the coast of British Columbia, Canada will draw Siberian-originated air into North America. The position of that high pressure will be crucial to developing a northwest to southeast wind aimed at Illinois from northwest Canada.

articles.title: Is climate change really something we need to stress about?
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Is climate change really something we need to stress about? Fiona Katauskas asks that question. She asks if it's something we should worry about at all. She's also asking if there's any need to worry about it at all, given the current global warming situation.

articles.title: Agri damage caused by Uwan at P3.17B
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: Agricultural damage caused by Super Typhoon Uwan has reached P3.17 billion. 153,493 metric tons from 25,996 hectares was lost. 66.43 percent of the affected area has a chance of recovery, while the remaining 33.57 percent is not.

articles.title: Measuring poverty in the age of climate change
articles.author: Knut Ostand Mohamed Shahudh
articles.summary: This year's Global MPI Report 2025 covers 109 countries representing 6.3 billion people. 18.3% of the global population live in multidimensional poverty, most of them in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. In the Philippines, 3.9% of population are multidimensionally poor, while another 5.2% are at risk. The report highlights air pollution in Metro Manila and flooding in southern provinces as major climate hazards that threaten progress toward Sustainable Development Goals.

articles.title: Rural Wairarapa communities on climate change frontline
articles.author: RNZ
articles.summary: Droughts, long hot days, more pests and invasive plants, and increasingly severe weather are all risks faced by the Wairarapa rural community. Representatives from the Carterton council rural advisory group, Masterton, Carterton and South Wirarapa district councils attended a workshop this week. The emergency operations centre at Greater Wellington was activated three times this year. The last time it was activated was in June 2021 for the Wellington South Coast swells.

articles.title: 10 years after Paris climate agreement: Did the world save itself, or sleepwalk into disaster?
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Ten years ago leaders announced the Paris Climate Agreement with historic optimism. The world now confronts a stark question: did the planet change course, or did emissions outpace ambition? The 1.5°C rise in temperature is the main concern for the world's leaders.

articles.title: Do Just One Thing: Saturday, Nov. 15, 2025
articles.summary: Opt for daytime flights instead of nighttime ones, because contrails and cirrus clouds form by aircraft trap heat and contribute to warming only at night. During the day, clouds help reflect sunlight back into space, offsetting some of the impact. Pack light. Every pound less means less fuel burned and fewer emissions.

articles.title: ‘Let's choose life – for the planet and for ourselves'
articles.summary: COP30 Brazil is a pivotal milestone in the global fight against climate change, tasked with building on the Paris Agreement's momentum. The planet continues to warm and scientists warn that current targets may not prevent a catastrophic temperature spike. The focus on implementation is a welcome shift, but words alone won't cool the Earth.

articles.title: World Insights: Melting Arctic fuels shipping surge, heightening safety risks
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: The dramatic retreat of Arctic ice is opening new shipping routes. Scientists across several countries are accelerating research and technology to help protect vessels, crews and glaciers in a warming world, according to the book "Glaciers and Ice Sheets in a Warming World: Impacts and Outcomes".

articles.title: First Freeze Dates Have Trended Nearly Two Weeks Later In Some SD Cities Since 1970, ...
articles.author: Yankton Daily Press
articles.summary: The first freeze dates across South Dakota are trending later in the year. This has lengthened the growing season while prolonging the risks from weeds, pests and wildfires.       in South Dakota, the first freeze date is trending later.

articles.title: 4 killed as migrant boats capsize off Libyan coast
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: At least four people were killed when two boats carrying 95 migrants capsized off the coast of the western Libyan city of Al Khums. The two incidents occurred on Thursday, the Libyan Red Crescent said on its official Facebook page. The Red Crescent posted the statement on Saturday.

articles.title: DOH: Climate Change Worsens Dengue, Leptospirosis Outbreaks
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: The Department of Health warned that climate change is exacerbating public health woes as it increases the risks of contracting diseases like dengue and leptospirosis. 'Climate change is heating our temperature. And because the temperature is getting hotter, the so-called vectors are multiplying — the mosquitoes,' the department said.

articles.title: Thousands hit streets of Belém to call for action during crucial Cop30 summit
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Funeral for fossil fuels held as part of Great People's March calling for governments to step up climate efforts. It was held in memory of fossil fuel industry workers who died in the last few decades due to climate change-related problems.

articles.title: Argentina Fire
articles.author: Citrus County Chronicle
articles.summary: Firefighters are working to control a fire at an industrial park in Ezeiza, Argentina, on Saturday, November 15, 2025, and will probably put out the blaze soon.    i.e. the fire is caused by an electrical fault.

articles.title: Fighting climate change with imaginative methods in East-Timor
articles.author: France24
articles.summary: As countries gather in Brazil for the COP 30 climate change conference, FRANCE 24 travels to East Timor, where global warming is wreaking havoc on the environment. France 24 is on a mission to monitor the situation in East Timorese.

articles.title: Be adult about climate change
articles.summary: The percentage of people who will be exposed to heat waves during their lifetime grew from 10% for people of high socioeconomic status who were born in 1960 to 79% for those born in 2020. The newer members of the human race will not be thanking us if we don't act now.
